text: <@U013A8TCPDK> has joined the channel
<@U013A8TCPDK> set the channel purpose: Given the digital age we live in, smartphones are becoming more of a necessity for everyday life. Are they necessary for children, and if so, from what age?
purpose: Given the digital age we live in, smartphones are becoming more of a necessity for everyday life. Are they necessary for children, and if so, from what age?

text: I agree!

elements.text: I agree!

text: <@U013A8TCPDK> set the channel topic: Should children have mobile devices like smartphones?
topic: Should children have mobile devices like smartphones?

text: So, let's get our definitions; child=

elements.text: So, let's get our definitions; child=

text: Neccessary=

elements.text: Neccessary=

text: age 12 and under?

elements.text: age 12 and under?

text: ok

elements.text: ok

text: Child - I would use school age - i.e. 5-16. 17+ young adults maybe?

elements.text: Child - I would use school age - i.e. 5-16. 17+ young adults maybe?

text: I don't believe in people being born after the year 2000.

elements.text: I don't believe in people being born after the year 2000.

text: I normally call 13-17 teenager

elements.text: I normally call 13-17 teenager

text: I guess it kind of falls under the discussion question of "... if so, from what age?"

elements.text: I guess it kind of falls under the discussion question of "... if so, from what age?"

text: My reasoning for 16 - is that at that age, children can start making some fairly important life decisions on their own (legally) without the need for parental consent, so maybe upper limit is 15 by my own reasoning!

elements.text: My reasoning for 16 - is that at that age, children can start making some fairly important life decisions on their own (legally) without the need for parental consent, so maybe upper limit is 15 by my own reasoning!

text: What is our definition of "necessary'

elements.text: What is our definition of "necessary'

text: I would be happy to agree to 16+ being considered young adult based on how that fits into NZ legality

elements.text: I would be happy to agree to 16+ being considered young adult based on how that fits into NZ legality

text: Therefore 15 and under being considered children

elements.text: Therefore 15 and under being considered children

text: Even if we agree on what a child is, can we really reach a consensus that the term "necessary" is even relevant here?

elements.text: Even if we agree on what a child is, can we really reach a consensus that the term "necessary" is even relevant here?

text: I’m fine with that for the purpose of this discussion:)

elements.text: I’m fine with that for the purpose of this discussion:)

text: Definition of necessary - hmm, that is a BIG question. Necessary implies essential, as if one could not survive without something, i.e. a cell phone. Actually - the question is very broad. Is a tablet / ipad considered a mobile device?

elements.text: Definition of necessary - hmm, that is a BIG question. Necessary implies essential, as if one could not survive without something, i.e. a cell phone. Actually - the question is very broad. Is a tablet / ipad considered a mobile device?

text: Necessary for whose survival/wellbeing?

elements.text: Necessary for whose survival/wellbeing?

text: Necessary can only be determined upon personal circumstances

elements.text: Necessary can only be determined upon personal circumstances

text: I feel it's going to be difficult to answer the question "Should children have mobile devices ...." as the description then broadens the question into almost another direction by adding  "Are they necessary ..."

elements.text: I feel it's going to be difficult to answer the question "Should children have mobile devices ...." as the description then broadens the question into almost another direction by adding  "Are they necessary ..."

text: This seems to be a question about the sovereignty of a family unit/parent/caregiver under lawful circumstances, over decisions pertaining to the particular lifestyle of their child. The parent/caregiver only, has the authority to decide issues of this sort.

elements.text: This seems to be a question about the sovereignty of a family unit/parent/caregiver under lawful circumstances, over decisions pertaining to the particular lifestyle of their child. The parent/caregiver only, has the authority to decide issues of this sort.

text: I personally don't think there is anything particularly wrong with children having smartphones / devices - very handy for them to contact parents etc., but just not sure about the descriptor "necessary".

elements.text: I personally don't think there is anything particularly wrong with children having smartphones / devices - very handy for them to contact parents etc., but just not sure about the descriptor "necessary".

text: <@U014AL8B2TA> Yes, I would agree with that.

elements.text: Yes, I would agree with that.

text: There may be a time when in order to attend a particular school you are required to allow your child to use a device, but even then, the State should protect the family unit's sovereignty to choose how they bring up their child.

elements.text: There may be a time when in order to attend a particular school you are required to allow your child to use a device, but even then, the State should protect the family unit's sovereignty to choose how they bring up their child.

text: I think it is ok for children to have a phone from a certain age (as determined by parent/caregiver) but I also think they should first have a 'dumb' phone before having a smartphone

elements.text: I think it is ok for children to have a phone from a certain age (as determined by parent/caregiver) but I also think they should first have a 'dumb' phone before having a smartphone

text: The last few weeks are a case in point - 1,000s of tablets sent to students of all ages who otherwise would have had no access to online learning, so in this instance - it was necessary for them to access education. But somewhat exceptional circumstances.

elements.text: The last few weeks are a case in point - 1,000s of tablets sent to students of all ages who otherwise would have had no access to online learning, so in this instance - it was necessary for them to access education. But somewhat exceptional circumstances.

text: A parent may have to work with a school to find a solution, but parents should never be forced by the state or any other institution to give up their freedoms.

elements.text: A parent may have to work with a school to find a solution, but parents should never be forced by the state or any other institution to give up their freedoms.

text: I would argue no, it wasn't necessary, it was just idea.

elements.text: I would argue no, it wasn't necessary, it was just idea.

text: ideal.

elements.text: ideal.

text: I agree magnetmussel. Not necessary but ideal

elements.text: I agree magnetmussel. Not necessary but ideal

text: Hmmm - how would they than access online teaching (i.e if no other devices in the home?)

elements.text: Hmmm - how would they than access online teaching (i.e if no other devices in the home?)

text: Becoming increasingly more important

elements.text: Becoming increasingly more important

text: Otherwise we would be making the assumption that the only kind of learning that can happen under lockdown was online.

elements.text: Otherwise we would be making the assumption that the only kind of learning that can happen under lockdown was online.

text: The school is working for the family unit, under the parent's jurisdiction, not the other way around.

elements.text: The school is working for the family unit, under the parent's jurisdiction, not the other way around.

text: For example, those who home school have decided that they won't hire an institution to teach their kids. That is their prerogative. Those who decide that the institution is ideal for their kids send their kids to school, and during lockdown, onto their devices. It is their prerogative.

elements.text: For example, those who home school have decided that they won't hire an institution to teach their kids. That is their prerogative. Those who decide that the institution is ideal for their kids send their kids to school, and during lockdown, onto their devices. It is their prerogative.

text: Yes, that's true - plenty of other life-skills to learn. Don't know if I am giving too much away about me personally, but I am a violin teacher - without my students having access to some means of being online, I would have had no way to teach my students for the past 8 weeks (I manage to cnnect with all but 3)

elements.text: Yes, that's true - plenty of other life-skills to learn. Don't know if I am giving too much away about me personally, but I am a violin teacher - without my students having access to some means of being online, I would have had no way to teach my students for the past 8 weeks (I manage to cnnect with all but 3)

text: I think other mobile devices like a family laptop or computer are necessary for a child’s learning purposes. But smartphones tend to be used for entertainment and social media primarily. So I wouldn’t say they were necessary for kids. Probably the most necessary element of a smartphone for a young person would be fitting in with their peers. And that kind of behaviour doesn’t start til around puberty age, like 12-13.

elements.text: I think other mobile devices like a family laptop or computer are necessary for a child’s learning purposes. But smartphones tend to be used for entertainment and social media primarily. So I wouldn’t say they were necessary for kids. Probably the most necessary element of a smartphone for a young person would be fitting in with their peers. And that kind of behaviour doesn’t start til around puberty age, like 12-13.

text: And some parents and students are opting to still learn from home from next week, so I will continue with their online lessons until such time as they decide to return to school.

elements.text: And some parents and students are opting to still learn from home from next week, so I will continue with their online lessons until such time as they decide to return to school.

text: I think the earlier kids get into smartphones the less time they spend running around, using their imagination, and all that good old fashioned entertainment

elements.text: I think the earlier kids get into smartphones the less time they spend running around, using their imagination, and all that good old fashioned entertainment

text: Over the last couple of months virtual teaching has become necessary for universities etc. but generally speaking, this has been primarily done over laptops/tablets/desktops rather than smartphones

elements.text: Over the last couple of months virtual teaching has become necessary for universities etc. but generally speaking, this has been primarily done over laptops/tablets/desktops rather than smartphones

text: <@U013M1S8U67> - yup - some of students used their parents mobile devices - especially the younger ones.

elements.text: - yup - some of students used their parents mobile devices - especially the younger ones.

text: perhaps we are slipping slightly off the topic?

elements.text: perhaps we are slipping slightly off the topic?

text: My point is that we cannot, as a group decide that this is a necessity. No other technology is considered a necessity by the state. As long as you're not breaking the law, outside the family unit, there is no such thing as "necessary". The family unit decides how their family will live and what will be considered "necessary.' No group can make those decisions.

elements.text: My point is that we cannot, as a group decide that this is a necessity. No other technology is considered a necessity by the state. As long as you're not breaking the law, outside the family unit, there is no such thing as "necessary". The family unit decides how their family will live and what will be considered "necessary.' No group can make those decisions.

text: Yeah I guess we could isolate the discussion to smartphones in particular

elements.text: Yeah I guess we could isolate the discussion to smartphones in particular

text: On that basis, the right of parental sovereignty, I would argue that we cannot reach a consensus that any technology is a necessity, regardless of how ideal we think it is in our own lives. I would argue that, no, there is no "should" in this area.

elements.text: On that basis, the right of parental sovereignty, I would argue that we cannot reach a consensus that any technology is a necessity, regardless of how ideal we think it is in our own lives. I would argue that, no, there is no "should" in this area.

text: So, do we answer the question - or the broader description? My best answer to the actual question is "maybe" depending on the family and circumstances.

elements.text: So, do we answer the question - or the broader description? My best answer to the actual question is "maybe" depending on the family and circumstances.

text: I agree with <@U014AL8B2TA> that we cannot decide this as 'one size fits all.' each family unit must decide how it works within their personal circumstances
